Author: 2 April 2001
Review: One of the best adaptations of a Stephen King story ever.
Review_Url: Stand By Me is yet another one of the stories made into a movie from the author who has had more stories made into movies than any other author in history, Stephen King. Clearly, the central character here is Gordie Lachance, from whose point of view the story is told and who obviously symbolizes King himself, given many of his characteristics as well as some of the content of the film. This movie is literally filled with actors who have achieved varying degrees of success over the years, such as Jerry O'Connell, who played Vern, River Phoenix, who could have been bigger than Leonardo DiCaprio if he hadn't died, Corey Feldman, who has grown into an unenviable but visible existence, Kiefer Sutherland, who has become an excellent and very well known actor, John Cusack can be seen in a small role as Gordie's late brother, and of course, Richard Dreyfuss, who played the narrator and Gordie as an adult, has remained famous but originally achieved fame more than a decade before Stand By Me was filmed or the original story was even written.

The film is full of great insights into the minds of a group of four boys who decide they want to see what a dead body looks like, and it sparks their interest even more that they actually knew this dead person. A young boy's mind is full of many things, they feel lost sometimes, strong at others, but mostly they feel invinceable. This is a perfect little film.

Author: 10 July 2005
Review: Four boys go on a quest to find not only a dead body the true meaning of friendship and reality.
Review_Url: Hands down this is my favorite movie. (With the Sandlot in second place). My mom got this movie for me when i was about 12. I saw it the first time and realized that i had friends like that. The movie is definitely one every teenage kid should see. I think it is more of a movie for boys but girls can get out of it the same as the boys can. But the movie overall is great because its just about a four friends who have no experience with the "real world". They find out about a dead body and go in search to find it. At first they just do it to be famous and get a reward. But the quest of the boys throughout the movie reveal things that even themselves didn't know about. After it all, the boys find out about reality, and how it isn't glamorous. They realize that the body could of been them and they respect that. In my opinion the point of the movie was not to have you think of when you were 12 and your good friends but to think of what you have now, and what you do with it. In the end Gordie tells us what happens to each and how each kind of go their separate ways. (Such as the last scene of the movie). This is definitely a movie to not only rent but buy. I tip my hat to Reiner.

Review_Url: This movie has such a punch. A group of boys (culled from some of the best child actors of the time) make a gruesome discovery. How they handle it will affect them their whole lives. But the story is as much about their pasts and their connection to one another. I just wrote comments on "The Breakfast Club." I felt that movie lacked chemistry. While every type was represented, it just didn't cook the way this one does. Part of it is that these boys, while in some ways disenfranchised, are not open books. As they interact, their dreams and hopes are drawn from them. Some seem quite settled, but when push comes to shove, they have vulnerabilities. The stories they tell give us insight into their souls. From what has happened to some of the actors, it makes one wonder if some of that suffering came from within them. There are intense scenes. There is bragging and one- upsmanship along the way. And nothing is simple or trite. On of the best movies of our time.

Author: 26 September 2009
Review: "But kids lose everything unless there's someone there to look out for them".
Review_Url: I was already well beyond my formative pre-teen years when I first saw this film, but there's no denying that if you grew up in small town America, this is about as close as you get to capturing the essence of childhood friendships that remain with you forever, even after time and distance take their eventual toll. Director Rob Reiner skillfully crafts a compelling tale from a Stephen King short story, layering it with various sub-texts that run the gamut from dealing with the town bully to confronting the loss of family. What's probably most remarkable about the picture are the performances that Reiner obtains from his young starring cast, most notably River Phoenix as Chris Chambers, and Wil Wheaton as his best friend Gordie Lachance. Told through the perspective of Wheaton's character, the film conjures up memories of the many trials and tribulations one faces while growing up, often unsure of oneself and even worse, feeling alone and disoriented when personal tragedy strikes and threatens to overwhelm one's very being. Yet the story never gets maudlin or depressing, there's enough youthful camaraderie and mischief on hand to keep the adventurous foursome going strong. Corey Feldman and Jerry O'Connell round out the group, and together they manage to grow and mature in a way that none of them could have imagined prior to starting their quest. Scored with a soundtrack that memorializes some of the great song hits from a half century ago, "Stand By Me" is a strange and wonderful journey, in it's own way reminding us of what might have been the best time of our lives. Sincerely.

Author: 24 August 2005
Review_Url: I saw this movie a few years ago and I instantly thought it was great. It's a memorable story (adapted from an unusual literary venture for Stephen King) about four 12-year-old boys in 1959 who go in search of a dead body. Everything about this movie was memorable: the script, the acting, and most of all, the four boys. All of them had distinct personalities and backgrounds and didn't blend into each other like so many other movies like this. My favorite character was Chris Chambers, who was not only cute but a "bad boy" with a heart of gold (also the breakout role for River Phoenix). This is a must-see for anyone who likes a good movie. The only problem I had with this movie was that I found it unrealistic. The 12-year-old boys in the movies cussed every two words, smoked cigarettes regularly, and talked admiringly in detail about some girl's boobs. I found this unusual even for 1959. I was 12 once, and most of the boys I knew rarely cussed, never smoked anything, and were just a smidge too far from puberty to talk about a girl's boobs in detail. However, these small qualities are redeemed. This is a great movie from the great Stephen King.

Author: 26 March 2003
Review_Url: The early death of River Phoenix has given his films a posthumous lustre; but 'Stand By Me', though not without merits, is not a great film.  It gets some things right: for example, it has the courage to tell a tale of four decidedly pre-pubescent children, and while they do not necessarily make pleasant company, its a relief to see a "rights of passage" film not entirely shaped by a story of first love.  But the characters are disappointly archetypal: the sensitive writer, the wise gang leader, the stupid fat kid and the wild one; and the dialogue and story are at times weighed down by the burden of implied significance.  Also hard to understand is why the older boys who also appear should be quite so wound up by the film's (much younger) heroes.  The low key ending is also undermined by the sentimental wrapping provided by the narrator.  Read Roddy Doyle's novel 'Paddy Clarke Ha-ha-ha' for a less heavy handed story of children growing up by stealth.

Author: 14 May 2005
Review: Stephen King always knows how to do nostalgia
Review_Url: Four boys, Gordie (Wil Wheaton), Chris( River Phoenix), Teddy (Corey Feldman) and Vern (Jerry O'Connell), go on a two-day hike to find a dead body along the railroad tracks in 1950's Oregon. Coming as it does from a Stephen King story (called "The Body"), one might assume that "Stand by Me" is a horror story. In fact, it is nothing of the sort. It really shows these boys slowly but surely coming of age, especially when they meet up with local hoodlum Ace Merrill (Kiefer Sutherland). As is a recurring theme in Stephen King's stories, the boys come from rather unhappy homes, and the four of them getting together as a group is their only escape, which King also explored in "It" and "Hearts in Atlantis".

So it actually is a small, but very involving coming-of-age film.

The strengths and weaknesses of the script are often a direct reflection of its source (a Stephen King novella), with dialogue keenly tuned to the period (who was stronger, Superman or Mighty Mouse?), but overloaded with a superabundance of barf jokes, fart jokes, jerking off jokes, and so forth. It's too bad, because the film is miles above its competition, even with the totally unnecessary voice-over narration (read by Richard Dreyfuss) used to frame the central story.

Review: Affectionate enough tale of four youngsters discovering all kinds of strife and truths, under a canopy of highly delicate comedy and enjoyable characterisation.
Review_Url: There's a point in Rob Reiner's pleasing 1985 film Stand by Me in which the primary characters themselves, in the form of four young boys of around about double figures in age, identify the trip they're all going on as anything but "just a load of fun" or an excuse to "have fun" or that they 'ought' to be having fun. Where the allure of doing something a little rebellious and sneaking off with three friends for a few days so as to visit a yet undiscovered crime scene sounded like a great time prior to taking off, it is only half way through the journeying that the real world out and away from your home does not necessarily adhere to your initial vision. In a certain sense, we feel the same way about the film: an unobtrusive and light hearted comedy about a bunch of boys breaking all the rules and having fun in the process on the surface but something much more beneath that. There is nothing funny about what the four primary child characters go through in Stand by Me, nothing funny about the realities they face nor what it is they both experience and learn as a result of what they do. Like the boys at the soul of the film itself going through what they're going through, the audience themselves are invited to take a step back and really mediate on what it is we truly think about what's transpiring before our eyes.

Author: 5 June 2007
Review_Url: Following the success of This Is Spinal Tap, Golden Globe nominated director Rob Reiner (Misery, A Few Good Men) brought out this fantastic coming-of-age drama. Based on a book called "The Body" by Stephen King, this film has Gordie Lachance, or The Writer (Richard Dreyfuss) looking back on his younger days when he and three close friends go on an adventure to find the body of a missing kid, presumed dead. The four characters are all lovable, including leader and best friend Chris Chambers (Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade's River Phoenix), Gordie himself (Wil Wheaton), quite smart glasses wearing Teddy Duchamp (The Goonies' Corey Feldman), and large wimpy and simple minded Vern Tessio (Scream 2's Jerry O'Connell). Along the way, they encounter the junk yard owner and his legendary dog Chopper, a speeding train on a bridge they are walking on which they jump from, camp fire chats (including the hilarious Larass barfing story), crossing the lake of leeches, and ultimately, they become closer than they did before, if only it lasted. They are also being followed by older boys, trying to get their first, including hateful leader Ace Merrill (Kiefer Sutherland). Also starring Casey Siemaszko as Billy Tessio, Gary Riley as Charlie Hogan, Bradley Gregg as Eyeball Chambers, Jason Oliver as Vince Desjardins and then quite unknown John Cusack as Denny Lachance. They do eventually find the body, but cover it back up and respect it, and all kids hardly see each other afterwards, even after their close bonds. Author: 21 April 2017
Review_Url: Upon learning of the death of a childhood friend, a story writer recalls an adventure that they shared with two other boys when they were twelve years old in this nostalgic coming-of-age drama starring Wil Wheaton and River Phoenix as the two young friends. The chemistry between Wheaton and Phoenix feels genuine throughout and highlights of their adventure include a near miss with a speeding train, an engrossing campfire story about a pie eating contest and a leech incident. Their goal of seeing a dead body that they have heard about is pretty interesting too. This is one of those movies where the journey is more important than the destination though and it is a bit of an uneven ride with little sense of tension or urgency in the air as the boys talk about random topics such as Disney characters and food while casually making their way to where they believe the body is located. A major part of the film also involves the boys standing up their older brothers and other bigger kids, none of which is half as interesting as the way they confide in one another about their deepest fears and resentments during the course of their adventure. The final fifteen minutes or so of the film are quite intense though and one gets the sense of the boys being truly affected by their experiences, but one's mileage here will likely depend upon one's affection for nostalgia.

Review: Not what you'd expect from King
Review_Url: Many claim this to be the best adaptation of Stephen King. I will refrain from such claims until I saw them all (so far I have seen 14 out of around 80), but it sure is great. The story is not a typical King, but, even if I didn't know what I'm watching, I would recognize King by the overall atmosphere. This adventure is placed at the end of the '50s, also one of King's signatures, and followed by an excellent choice of music from that period. Fans of horror, fantasy and suspense adventure may be disappointed by the lack of all, cause this movie almost has no plot and it's based on characterization and human relationships. For just an hour and a half, that summarize two days of boys adventure, we get to know those four twelve years old boys so good that we get the impression we grew up together with them. Besides King's writing and Reiner's directing, great merits for such an impression go to four boys that will soon grow up into famous actors - star of Star Trek Wil Wheaton, prematurely deceased River Phoenix (who, strangely, dies prematurely in movie too), less famous but very productive Corey Feldman (Gremlins, Goonies, voice of Donatello in TMNT), Kiefer Sutherland and lots more of more or less known faces. All in all, if you don't expect a typical King and know how to enjoy good family drama, this movie would be a shame to miss.

Author: 24 January 2021
Review_Url:
Stand By Me is one of those truly special films that really only comes around once in a lifetime. Based on the novella "The Body" by Stephen King, Stand By Me follows a group of 4 friends who journey to find the body of a young man who has gone missing and is presumed to be dead. It's one of those stories that has a simple overarching plot, but layers it meaningful details along the way. It's not about "the destination" so much as it's about "the journey."
In this film, you'll find some of the most powerful child acting that may ever have been committed to screen, creating both a chemistry between each other and emotionally-charged scenes that deliver in the best possible way every single time. It presents a friendship that never leaves the audience wondering whether or not it's legitimate. These kids could easily have been friends for their entire lives based solely off what you see in the film. When they're happy, the audience is happy and, when the more emotional scenes come along, the audience is in on it just as much as the kids are.
The film, much like the novella it's adapted from, creates a lovable group of kids and portrays the struggles of coming to terms with mortality and the difficulties of growing up with less than supportive parents in a way that feels completely authentic.
Wil Wheaton is absolutely incredible as Gordie LaChance, a wannabe writer with a heart of gold for his friends; the late River Phoenix is absolutely the standout as the rugged street kid Chris Chambers, who was given the short end of the stick as a result of his family's name and affiliations; Corey Feldman is fantastic as Teddy Duchamp, a young boy layered with personal drama that directly plays into his conflicting character; and there's Jerry O'Connell as Vern Tessio who, despite being a really good actor that fit the part really well, comes off as the cheap comic relief character. He's not exactly the brightest in the group; he's very simple-minded. Yet together they created a great group of kids that pull you into the film and hold you there from beginning to end.
The soundtrack of this film is absolutely immaculate, drawing from classics from the likes of Buddy Holly and, of course, Ben E. King. It's an homage to a world of music we have all but forgotten in today's society, and it's really nice to look back on it. The soundtrack album of this film is truly every bit as good as the film itself.
The score is also really well done, in particular because it knows when to be quiet. It's an easy thing to slap some emotional music over more vulnerable scenes (it creates the "emotional manipulation" effect), but this film doesn't do that as much as it probably could've. During some of the more emotional and iconic scenes, the film doesn't have a musical score accompanying it. You just get the very natural feeling of someone opening up and expressing their feelings to a friend, and the choice to not have music and to let that happen organically was the perfect decision, in my opinion.
Stand By Me is a movie that is really meant to be experienced rather than talk about, and there isn't much I can say about it that will really do it justice, except to say that it's one of the very few movies I recommend to every single person. You need to see this at least once.

Review: Thoughtful Film Supported By First Rate Filmmaking
Review_Url:
Four friends go on a weekend adventure together in search of a body. A pretty simple logline. The film follows four preteen boys on their two day trek and with only a few exceptions stays on them for the 89 minute duration. The banter between them is, well, childish, but it's still entertaining. Its humorous and at times poignant. And cast members are all talented actors who make their lines work. However, I find River Phoenix definetly gives the best performance of the film. The amount of emotion and sincerity he can bring to a character at that age is remarkable. And its these deeper undercurrents that he and also his castmates can channel that makes this film. This film is what you might call 'coming of age' and is really a look at a certain stage in life. And Rob Reiner does an excellent job on conveying the particular atmosphere of this film. Everything about it from the lighting, score, design and narration adds to a certain tone and feeling to this film.
Despite the fact that its protagonists are kids Stand By Me is really made for adults. Its reminiscent of childhood(perhaps the one you wish you had)and viewing it with the hindsight of the future.

Author: 27 May 2021
Review: After all these years, Stand By Me has stood the test of time!
Review_Url: I first watched this movie with my best friend on August 22, 1986 at the Cortana Mall Cinema in Baton Rouge, LA. Not only was that the day it went into wide release, it also marked my friend's 18th birthday and I suggested watching this after spending some of that day at the Fun Fair Park amusement ride area. So the place was crowded by the time the movie began. There were plenty of laughs during much of the narrative and I remember being touched by some of the more emotional scenes. I don't remember if my friend liked it as much as I did (the only time I even remember him saying anything during the picture was during the scene after Will Wheaton's character shot the gun in the air and when he pointed it at Kiefer Sutherland's bully character, my friend said, "Kill him!"), but he must have still been in a good mood because we went bowling afterwards at Don Carter's. Anyway, I just watched it again at the Perkins Rowe Cinema today-since it's celebrating its 35th anniversary this year, it was only playing at 7:00 this evening-and it's even better than ever! I mean, besides Wheaton, Corey Feldman, Jerry O'Connell, and River Phoenix are aces as the four near-teen boys on their journey to find a dead body who was close to their age. And Kiefer was sure very effective as the bully, wasn't he? And kudos to Rob Reiner for truly understanding what it's like to feel so insecure while growing up with not-so-perfect livelihoods. Stephen King was so touched, he considered this one of the best of films adapted from his work. So, yes, I very highly recommend Stand By Me. P. S. When just watching this right now, I could've swore that one of the bullies surrounding Kiefer was also one of the bullies that surrounded Thomas F. Wilson's Biff Tannen in the first Back to the Future during that movie's '50s sequence. Sure enough, that bully that was in both this and BTTF was one Casey Siemaszko!

Review_Url: In Stand By Me, Rob Reiner has perfectly captured what it means to be a adolescent male among adolescent males. The story is built from the ground up, through anecdotes, gossip and whispers that may or may not be hard truths. Reputation is everything to these boys. We may never see the addled war veteran that is Teddy's abusive father, or the alcoholic criminals in Chris' family that give him such a bad reputation, but we feel their presence through their pained, clipped dialogue and the taunts of others. And still these bad people become dysfunctional male role models; Teddy fiercely defends the man who held his ears up against the oven, although he does not know why, and Gordie is fighting for the approval of parents who could not care less about him.

Author: 23 January 2022
Review_Url: There are rare occasions in film where every single little thing aligns right, and makes for something beautiful- Stand By Me is one of those films. I am far too young to have been from the 1950's growing up, and even far too young to have seen this movie when it was released- so I guess many may wonder why this one resonated with me so much. I grew up largely afraid, alone, friends came and go and for a little while there I had a small group of close friends I really enjoyed spending time with. We all ended up at different schools, in different lives, with very different opinions, and many different preferences. There probably won't be a time where we all stand in the same room again, but I have those memories- and nothing has ever captured that bittersweet feeling more than this movie. People, especially adults, never truly realize how lonely it can be being a kid- and its heartbreaking to see that this is the same throughout 3 completely separate generations. Wherever we fall in age, gender, race, or conformity, I think I will look back at this film- and know that at one time we were all just little kids like them- eager and afraid- and maybe, we are all still that way. Even just a little bit.

Review: It's a perfect instance of how Stephen King can write something other than horror.
Review_Url: Stand by Me (1986) This is coming-of-age drama film that tells the story of four boys in a small town in Oregon who go on a hike to find the dead body of a missing child. It is based on Stephen King's novella The Body. It stars Wil Wheaton, River Phoenix, Corey Feldman, and Jerry O'Connell. Each has had a decent career following this movie. Unfortunately, Phoenix died at a young age. He was a genuine talent. This was one of my favorite movies when I was a child. I still watch it here and there, when the mood hits, or the internet is down. It's definitely one to have a copy lying about. The chemistry of the characters engross you into a story of friendship, the kind you miss over the years. These boys are on that cusp of being a child, and becoming a teenager. I possessed the luxury of seeing this as a child, so I will always relate. I strongly suggest this film for parents of children at that age. But it's not just for them. Adults will love this movie too. It's a perfect instance of how Stephen King can write something other than horror.

Review: A thoroughly unforgettable coming of age film
Review_Url: This film, based on the novel 'The Body' by Stephen King, one of the astounding authors of our generation; comes a mesmerizing story of growing up and the emotional dilemmas in the lives of youths. Directed by Rob Reiner, this film tells the story of four 12-year old boys living in a tranquil town of Castle Rock, Oregon in the late 50s: Gordie Lachance (played by Wil Wheaton), a sensitive kid who faces disillusion by his father after the death of his older brother Denny and thus, feels lonely at home; Chris Chambers (played by River Phoenix), a tough, but peace-loving boy who is labeled by many as a bad kid after he was caught stealing milk money at school, and is plagued by guilt after since the incident; Teddy Duchamp (played by Corey Feldman), a flamboyant young man with abusive, war veteran father who once held his son's ear to the stove, requiring him to wear an ear piece; and Vern Tessio (played by Jerry O'Connell), a down-to-earth and overly cautious kid who also deals with a rude older brother. These preteens spend their summer in a tree house playing cards, smoking, and telling tall tales, until they hear the news about a dead kid their age gone missing after being hit by a train. So the four boys set out on a quest in search of him with nothing standing their way but a gang of older kids lead by bully Ace Merrill (played by Kiefer Sutherland). This story told is from narration by an older age Gordie (played by Richard Dreyfuss).

Review: Emotional, Poignant Tale About Growing Up!
Review_Url: Rob Reiner's Stand by Me is a wonderful, inspiring coming-of-age drama. Do not expect this film to be like a Disney film as it truly earns its R-rating. But you know, Reiner captures the essence of the teenage spirit. Humans, especially teens, curse all the time. Thankfully, Raynold Gideon's screenplay is incredibly realistic when it comes to depicting teenage friends with different personalities. I cried, I laughed, and I embraced the film. Although I was not yet born when the film was released, nostalgia hit me like a train. I was reminded of my own childhood and in particular could relate to the movie's main character, Gordie.

Author: 4 December 2012

In fact, the kids in the film look more like adults or kids playing adults in a movie, than actual kids. That is a general problem with films portraying children since adults write the script and therefore they make all the characters act and talk like adults.

Review: Excellent character study of the tender years of life.
Review_Url: You are 12 years old.You know nothing and are curious about everything.You surround yourself with friends who have that same distinction.You are in those tender years,your last years as a child.It's the best time in a person's life,or at least it should be.This is what Stand By Me represents to me personally.It isn't a story about four particular boys.It's a story about all of us and what we go through in those years.This is an excellent story,brilliantly casted and superbly directed by Rob Reiner.Kiefer Sutherland is profoundly convincing as the chief heavy,and perhaps deserved an Oscar nomination if he didn't receive one.Upon watching the film again for the first time in several years,I found that particular scene where River Phoenix's character,Chris Chambers,fades away as he walks off in the distance particularly sad.Little did we know then that this young man,who was perhaps the best young actor of his generation,would do just that only seven years later,dying tragically at the age of 23.The scene now has a profound sadness to it.Stand By Me is one of the best character studies I have ever seen,and an excellent film.

Review: Wonderfully done; one of the best Stephen King adaptations.
Review_Url: Anchored by four irresistible performances by the youthful leads, "Stand by Me" stands tall as one of the finest films to be derived from a Stephen King story (a novella originally titled "The Body"). If the prospective viewer is anything like this one, it will likely make you long for your lost childhood. The four main characters are well defined and very sympathetic, with most of them having to experience some painful thoughts and ideas.

Author: 20 February 2014
Review_Url: Rob Reiner's "Stand By Me" qualifies as a great movie. The Raynold Gideon and Bruce A. Evans screenplay is thoughtful, introspective, but appropriately melodramatic, with memorable dialogue. Reiner and his writers know when to swerve from comic hijinks to dramatic predicaments. Squeamish spectators who abhor profanity should be prepared for some naughty words. The film benefits from strong casting, with Kiefer Sutherland as a superb villain. The quartet of kids—River Phoenix, Will Wheaton, Corey Feldman, and Jerry O'Connell—are likable enough characters etched with enough quirks to make them interesting. They learn where a dead body--Ray Brower—can be located near a river and take a walk through the woods to get it. Meanwhile, Ace Merrill (Kiefer Sutherland) and his cronies take their cars. Mind you, "Stand By Me" is a coming-of-age story about troubled youth. Gordie Lachance (Will Wheaton) feels guilty about the death of his older brother Denny (John Cusack) who excelled at football. Denny was the apple of his father's eye. During a nightmare, Gordie dreams that his father told him that he should have died. Chris Chambers (River Phoenix) is the never-do-well kid, and his big brother runs with Ace. Reiner doesn't wear out our patience with his skillful adaptation of Stephen King's novella "The Body." Reiner relates his yarn from Gordie's perspective. Like all flashback tales, this one has an older actor (Richard Dreyfuss) reminiscing about his past. The semi-sort of happy ending is both downbeat and solemn. Definitely worth watching with several good scenes, like Ace running a truck off the highway during a chicken race, the railway bridge crossing, and the leech scene in the river with our quartet of heroes, stand out.

Author: 27 March 2006
Review_Url: The movie Stand by Me is a story about four close twelve year old friends growing up in rural Oregon who are bitten by the curiosity bug. The main Character, Gordie (Wil Wheaton), and his three friends, Chris (River Pheonix), Teddy (Corey Feldman), and Vern (Jerry O'Connell) set out on an adventure to find the body of Ray Brower. They had heard of his whereabouts by Vern's older brother and they were determined to find him. They incur many setbacks during their journey. They are bullied by the older boys of the town who are also trying to find the body and get the fame, attacked by the junkyard dog Chopper, almost getting run down by a train, and attacked by the swamp leaches. The boys learn many lessons on their journey, but more importantly they learn about life. The actual goal of Rob Reiner, director of the film, was to show that growing up has its ups as well as downs. All four of the main characters have had some trouble in their life. He showed this when Gordie's athletic brother was tragically killed in a car accident. By doing this, Reiner elaborates to the audience that bad things do happen to the best people. Chris and Teddy also have very neglecting fathers at their homes. Even though it is all fun and games on the hunt for the body, they still have a troubled life lingering in the background that they can not get away from. And good old Vern has an older brother who wreaks havoc in his life. He is actually one of the older bullies also on the hunt for the body. Reiner cannot make his point much clearer. One of the things I really loved about this movie is how few rules the young twelve year old boys had. The first evident thing is when the movie opens and they are smoking in their tree house. These boys smoke, shoot handguns in town, and cuss like sailors throughout the movie and know one seems to notice. Wow, the times sure have changed since I was a young child.

Author: 10 March 2010
Review_Url: I do believe the title of the story from which it came was "The Body", they instead named it "Stand by Me". Probably a wise decision as if it was named "The Body" anyone who was familiar with Stephen King, but not this particular story would automatically assume this was a horror movie. No, it is a coming of age type tale, a sort of buddy travel story on a smaller scope than other travel movies as these are kids and while they walk a fair distance they do not really go cross country or anything. The premise of the movie is that four friends are going along the train tracks in search of the body of a boy who was hit by a train I believe. During their travels they have their hardships, breakdowns, and very funny moments as well. The actors are all great, a lot of young talent though looking back now the best one was most likely River Phoenix who passed away I believe shortly after "Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade". I also enjoyed his performance in that movie although it was brief and I also enjoyed his performance in an earlier film "Explorers". Wil Wheaton I have not really seen in many movies since, I know he was in "Star Trek: The Next Generation" and I believe he writes for shows too, though I am not 100 percent sure of that. Feldman was also good in this, but he was actually a good actor, I think he just got typecast to much later in life where he and Corey Haim were in a lot of movies together. Both good actors, but I think they probably damaged each others careers by all the films they starred in together in a rather short span of time. This film is good though and I usually like a travel film. There are some issues though as I am just unsure of the gang led by Kiefer Sutherland as they seemed a rather strange addition to the film. I just do not see why they would even bother trying to find the body as if they did I am sure local authorities would probably pin the death on them. Still, Kiefer did a nice job as the sort of villain of the movie. All in all a good movie about kids who while on a trip to find something at the end discover some stuff about themselves and each other.

Review: The Characters And Actors Who Play Them Are More Important Than The Story
Review_Url: More notable for its characters (and the actors who played them) than for its story, "Stand By Me" is a pretty decent piece of movie-making. Taken from a Stephen King short story called "The Body," the movie is a sort of coming of age story that follows four boyhood friends on a camping trip the summer before they enter Junior High. Their goal: to find the body of a classmate who is presumed dead after going into the woods to pick blueberries. The movie is a flashback. It opens with an author (played by Richard Dreyfuss) reading a newspaper account of a friend who had been stabbed to death, and from his reflections on the incident comes this account of one of their adventures. Dreyfuss continues to do voice-over narration throughout the movie.

Review_Url: Okay, I can't understand why I haven't written a comment on "Stand by Me" until now, even though I watch it at least once a year. Author: 1 June 2009
Review: "Stand By Me" will forever stand the test of time.
Review_Url: The premise of "Stand By Me" is a rather simple one. A group of four tightly-knit friends living in a small Oregon town, circa 1959, set out on foot to find a dead body. What could easily have been a routine Stephen King horror show is instead an often touching and nostalgic story about the purity and innocence of friendship before the teenage years and adulthood sets in and sours the deal. Director Rob Reiner's best film by far, the subject matter will hit close to home to anyone who has ever had close friendships that crumbled before their time, regardless of what you went through together.

Review: Kind of like IT but without the scary clown!
Review_Url: This film stands the test of time and although I wasn't around in the fifties, I was at least lucky enough to have a few friends to go out and do things with. We never went on a trip to find a dead body, but hey, nothing ever happened around here, so we did what we could. I think it's a shame that certain groups of people won't ever understand this film, because they've never run around in a field playing Cowboys or Soldiers or had tea parties with the girls or any of the other things kids used to do, before technology and the need to grow up so quickly. And that's why I love this film, because although not a great deal happens as such, it really does take a snapshot of a childhood almost forgotten.

Author: 12 March 2015
Review: One of the great Love stories...
Review_Url: Before I saw the movie, I read the novella (THE BODY, by Stephen King) and was struck by the STYLE of the writing: it reminded me more than a little of a Ray Bradbury story. I enjoyed the story and looked forward to seeing the movie- but what I wasn't prepared for was the Emotional Impact the movie would have on me. When I walked out of the theater, my legs were weak. I went to my car and got in and sat behind the wheel for a long time thinking about the guys I'd grown up with. Most of them were dead or in jail by then (or should've been), but they'd been my FRIENDS and remembering them that evening, I couldn't help but break down. Sure, the movie is stylized and the dialogue retains that "Bradbury" feel, but STAND BY ME is one of those rare movies that (at least for me) sticks with you long after you've seen it. It's hard to watch because of the memories it dredges up, but I still see it whenever I can because sometimes, no matter how much it hurts, it's good to Remember.

Review_Url: Good coming of age film....this film has Gordie Lachance, or The Writer (Richard Dreyfuss) looking back on his younger days when he and three close friends go on an adventure to find the body of a missing kid, presumed dead. Along the way, they encounter the junk yard owner and his legendary dog Chopper, a speeding train on a bridge they are walking on which they jump from, camp fire chats (including the hilarious Larass barfing story), crossing the lake of leeches, and ultimately, they become closer than they did before, if only it lasted. They are also being followed by older boys, trying to get their first, including hateful leader Ace Merrill (Kiefer Sutherland). Also starring Casey Siemaszko as Billy Tessio, Gary Riley as Charlie Hogan, Bradley Gregg as Eyeball Chambers, Jason Oliver as Vince Desjardins and then quite unknown John Cusack as Denny Lachance. They do eventually find the body, but cover it back up and respect it, and all kids hardly see each other afterwards, even after their close bonds.

Review_Url: Rob Reiner's mid-80s breakthrough has aged wonderfully. The characters are rich and still feel fairly un-stereotypical and the performances are engaging and natural. It's rock solid basically - here the well-observed King gang-of-lads dynamic gets centre stage without any of the creepy stuff. Certain sequences still have a wild tension to them and the 50's jukebox soundtrack gives it a magically vivid sort of life that's hard to define, one of those rare period films which have an uncanny accuracy about them.

From the McGuffin of a dead body to the Pythonesque gross-out of the cherry pie eating contest, this may wear the clothes of a gentle-spirited coming-of-age tale, but the shadows cast by death, relationships and the slowly looming responsibilities of adulthood are longer and more profound than our memories of this film may let us think. Review_Url: I haven't read "The Body", the novella this movie was based on, but the film very much impressed me. It's 1959. Gordie Lachance (Wil Wheaton) and his friends Chris Chambers (River Phoenix), Teddy Duchamp (Corey Feldman), and Vern Tessio (Jerry O'Connell) are following the story of Ray Brower, a boy who vanished while picking berries. Vern overhears his older brother Billy Tessio (Casey Siemasko) talking about finding Brower's body, so he tells his friends and the four of them decide to go looking for him. Meanwhile Billy tells his friends about Brower's body as well, and the leader of the gang, John "Ace" Merrill (Kiefer Sutherland) decides to search as well. Along the we we learn several things about each of the characters and they learn things about each other. Gordie loves writing stories and telling stories, but is largely ignored by his parents who are grieving the death of Gordie's older brother Denny Lachance (John Cusack), whom Gordie idolized. Chris's family are largely made up of criminals and alcoholics, and thus people see Chris as merely another link in his family's chain. Teddy's dad suffered from fits and rage after returning home after World War 2, and burned both of Teddy's ears. And Vern is constantly teased for his weight and bullied by Billy. Eventually the group finds Brower's body, but then Merrill's gang shows up. After a confrontation, both groups decide to leave without Brower. The child actors are all great, and the characters are so real that I've met someone like each one of them throughout my life (personally, I think I'm like Gordie). Not to mention, the soundtrack is fantastic. I'm listening to Ben E King as I write this now. If you haven't seen it yet, do yourself a favor and check it out.

Review: Stand by this one with it's great and irreplaceable acting foursome
Review_Url: Stand By Me is one of those films with some really unforgettable moments, a few of them, cherished ones by four young actors who are so impressive in their roles, we're taken aback, by just how good they really are. The most obvious being a young gifted actor who died way young before his time. 10 something, Vern, a younger Jerry O'Connell, a fatty here (yes, the same guy, whose ordinary looks shot up, making him a romeo sort, later on) overhears a conversation about a dead body by some local thugs, while scrounging for cash underneath the porch of his house. He rushes back to tell his friends, and so begins a two day adventure to locate the body of a missing teen. Ideally this movie is one about the joys of friendship, where along the way they encounter adversity, home truths, imaginative stories, while also nearly getting run down by a train, on a tall bridge, that proved quite a hairy moment. And too we had that lake/leech scene, one of them getting inside Jerry's drawers. The fat kid story told in great visual flashback was another of the treats in this fine film, plus bad and abused kid, Teddy, an excellent Feldman, who spits water in Vern's ear. When seeing Phoenix in this, and seeing him in later films, he seemed so different or he had grown up really quick. He's the best buddy of the other kid, Wil Wheaton through which this simple story and those imaginative ones are told. Wheaton's star should of shone brighter when judged by this performance, where he was really the only one who lucked out, later on as an actor. And now to put a rain on their damper, are the thugs in a convertible out to track down the body too, headed by Sutherland, who likes to smash a row of letter boxes with his baseball bat. The film's flow never bores or disappoints, and we learn things we wish we didn't about some of these poor kid's childhoods. Richard Dreyfuss as an older Wheaton adds a nice touch at the start, reminiscing, when reading one of the tabloids involving murdered best friend, Phoenix, while he returns at the end, in front of a computer screen, the author at work. The end where there's a standoff between the two groups again, failed to disappoint. This is a thoroughly enjoyable film. A near perfect film, it's fiftie's period captured beautifully. As a movie lover, it's a film, I urge you to see, if you haven't. Another scene of mention was in the candy store, Wheaton and the older owner, sharing conversation regarding the older and more favorable brother, (John Cusack) who had recently died, Wheaton, the excluded, the centre of blame by his father. It's almost impossible to fault this film of top notch and believable acting, Sutherland, making great on his role as a truly scary thug, threatening with a knife, where the younger group won't back down.

Review_Url: Director Rob Reiner skillfully crafts a compelling tale from a Stephen King short story, layering it with various sub-texts that run the gamut from dealing with the town bully to confronting the loss of family. What's probably most remarkable about the picture are the performances that Reiner obtains from his young starring cast, most notably River Phoenix as Chris Chambers, and Wil Wheaton as his best friend Gordie Lachance. Told through the perspective of Wheaton's character, the film conjures up memories of the many trials and tribulations one faces while growing up, often unsure of oneself and even worse, feeling alone and disoriented when personal tragedy strikes and threatens to overwhelm one's very being. Yet the story never gets maudlin or depressing, there's enough youthful camaraderie and mischief on hand to keep the adventurous foursome going strong. Corey Feldman and Jerry O'Connell round out the group, and together they manage to grow and mature in a way that none of them could have imagined prior to starting their quest. Scored with a soundtrack that memorializes some of the great song hits from a half century ago, "Stand By Me" is a strange and wonderful journey, in it's own way reminding us of what might have been the best time of our lives.

Review_Url: 'Stand By Me' is told in the form of a memoir, as established writer Gordie Lachance (Richard Dreyfuss), stunned by a local newspaper item about the death of a close friend, sits in his car, remembering back to 1959. Then, in the fullness of late summer, he and three of his friends embarked on an adventure that changed the course of their very carefree existence: a journey deep into the nearby woods to find the body of one of their very own missing classmates. Weeks prior, Ray Brower had disappeared and was presumed dead by authorities; now, armed with a veiled suggestion that his remains rest by a lake near where train tracks cross through the woods, the four hike up to the woodland grave-site to discover the body, bring it back to town and be hailed as heroes by the media.

It manages to get a harrowing, enjoyable, simple and beautiful story into 90 mins and is riveting to watch.  No other movie has captured the essence of being twelve so well.  Forget the Goonies or Home Alone or any of that other stuff, this is a kids movie and an adults movie at the same time.  It taps into how you miss being twelve, even when your thirteen! This is a movie that always brings a smile to your face and can be watched time and time again.

When I watch Magnolia or Boggie Nights, there are scenes that, I just keep silence, I don't know why. Wheter if I have no words, or I'm shocked, I keep silence for almost the entire film. The story in Stand by Me is actually simple: in a small US town, end of the 50's, a small group of 12-almost 13 year old boys escape on the search of a teenager's dead body, so they can come back home and be awarded as heroes. Easy thing. Sho why is this so special? It's not the story, is the characters. Based on Stephen King's The Body, director Rob Reiner grabbed a cast of kids that, in my opinion, wheren't actors playing those characters but rather those characters in the flesh, with their pros and cons. Stand By Me is just a classic film about growing up, and if we aren't kids all.

Author: 11 June 2008
Review_Url: Yes, this movie is definitely sad and you just don't feel the same after watching it. It holds a special place in my heart, especially the unfortunate fact that not only did actor River Phoenix die in the movie, but in real life too! If you've never seen Stand By Me, I highly recommend seeing it uncut instead of watching it on a channel like AMC. Not because of the profanity itself, rather because you need to experience what these boys truly said to each other and how it relates to their emotions so you can fully grasp what the movie's message is all about - how short life really is. I think the saddest line in this movie is when the Writer (Dreyfus) talks about how friends come in and out of your life like "bus-boys in a restaurant". Man, that is very true and very sad to think about. I've been trying to find a best friend I knew when I was 12 and to this day, I cannot locate him. For all I know, he could be deceased. I also used to walk with childhood friends along a railroad track near my grandmother's house in the summertime, so that part brings back fond memories too. The Stephen King novella Stand By Me is based on is also very emotional and I recommend reading it first to get a taste of what Reiner's film will be. It's unforgettable and timeless. Plus, I guarantee your eyes will leak tears by the end credits.

Review: An incredibly important and profound story - this movie is a life-altering experience
Review_Url: There is no questioning the significance of this film, describing a period in time and the way society was during that time, but what has amazed me, the second time viewing it, is the purity that characterizes this movie, and in particular its 4 main characters. This movie is so smart in describing the complexities of the minds of four young teens, how their nature and nurture has shaped them into the personalities they now carry, and how these traits and characteristics are influenced and changed themselves throughout moments in life, and by interacting with others. There is almost a post-war melancholy lingering over the air in this town of Oregon, Portland where these four kids happen to live in 1956. This group of friends bond over the support and comfort they find in each other, being 4 kids trying to survive in a period of their lives where everything is so intense and confusing, and where they've found themselves pretty much on their own, without the support of their families. The bravery of these four kids (and yes, even Vern's) inspires me, their willingness to plough on and to continually try to make sense of what this world has given them. The screenwriter and director have created incredibly profound and deep characters in these kids, while still not taking away their innocence and youth. When I watch the games they play, the manners they use, I'm reminded of the things I held important in that truly magical time of my life, like the sacred importance of a pinky swear, or the two punches for flinching annoyance. To me this is a story that pretty much any person can relate to, as it symbolizes a period in the life of someone where they felt lost, terrified, completely isolated, but not defeated. The need that Gordie feels to find the dead body is essentially a need to make sense of it all, of the things that happened in his life; why his brother had to die, why his dad never seemed to show any interest in him, why he felt he would never be able to amount to anything. These four kids are oppressed in a society that treats them with indifference and where they're victims of incessant bullying, and through this journey, they are able to fight through those feelings by exposing themselves to situations that push them to the brink and essentially, make them face those emotions of injustice head on. When I compare the world that these kids live in to the one my generation lives now, one thing remains the same: it is exhausting a job to try to make sense of everything that is happening around you. And in a world where nothing seems to be right and within your control, these kids find a mission that makes sense to them, one simple adventure that no one can take away from them, something that is within their control. And through this simple plan that only they have thought of, through this journey outside the confinements of this empty town they were brought up in, they could find the strength to face their deepest fears and to be the most vulnerable, in the company of true friends, where no real judgement and mockery can be found. Not all of these 4 heroes ended up truly succeeding in life, and that's okay because the truth is few of us will ever reach a true sense of achieving in life. But just like the narrator of this story, as long as we are able to remember that period in our lives that was the toughest, yet the most magical and intense period of our youth, as long as we find people to share a trip to the woods like these teens did, then we will capture a moment, a moment in our lives that was shared and experienced with certain souls that will never truly go away. And maybe a life filled with moments like these will truly suffice.

This movie is very faithful to the short story, which is beautiful. Stephen King from IT, to the Green Mile, to The Body, has always been able to produce an incredible work of art. From the books to the movies I always find myself at a loss of words. The movie is 10/10 for me. From the heartfelt realization of adulthood that this movie portrays (from the mind of a 12 year old in the story, obviously written by an adult), you understand themes and elements that portray to your daily life.
My favorite instance of writing in the short story being Chris (at 12 years old) understanding the interweaving elements of being an adult with adult ideas stemming from childhood struggles, realized at the precise point In time that it happens (when he's 12). Chris understands his current status in life, and makes sure that main protagonist Gordie understands that life is really real through the eyes of an adult.
I'm on the verge of turning 25, and the elements brought forth in this movie/in the short story for which it's based off of (The Body by Stephen King), are profoundly poetic and beautiful.
Within each scene you understand the struggles that each character is going through, only made true through your own thoughts creates through the movie/short story. Every point made and thematic element is understandable and heartfelt.
This story is truly incredible and worthy of a 10/10 rating. Very moving. Thank you again Stephen King

Author: 20 June 2014
Review: "You never have friends as good as the ones you had when you were twelve"
Review_Url: Stand By Me is the story of one-of-a-kind friendships. The movie starts out with a man writing a book recalling that "you never have friends as good as the ones you had when you were twelve". The author is who the movie revolves around, Gordie Lachance. Gordie (Wil Wheaton), Chris (River Phoenix), Teddy (Corey Feldman), and Vern (Jerry O'Connell) are four friends who embark on a journey of their life at the age of twelve. They set out to find the body of a dead kid, whom Vern overhears his brother stating the boy's location, but the foursome end up facing many obstacles along the way including a bully, Ace, played by Keifer Sutherland. While the boys are going to a grim destination, the bond and adventure that they endure is one that will last them a lifetime. A theme of this film would be to enjoy your childhood because growing up sucks and happens way faster than you realize. Gordie realizes this after the death of his older brother at which point he becomes invisible to his parents. All four of the boys came back from their journey with a new sense of maturity. I think seeing the dead boy along with the run-in with Ace's gang contributed to that along with other iconic scenes such as sleeping in the woods, Chopper, and swimming with the leeches. Another good movie that has the same theme as Stand By Me would be The Goonies. Both movies have a group of kids set out on an adventure that end up growing a little on the way. The scene in which Gordie and Chris are talking about Gordie taking advanced classes when they go back to school uses lighting to contribute to the theme. The lighting is soft on Gordie which makes him seem very childlike and hard on Chris with makes him seem more mature. This was kind of ironic as Chris was the one that was supposed to be the trouble maker and who I think would be considered childish whereas Gordie is more mature most of the movie. For example, Gordie doesn't horse around as much as the other three boys. I think the radio music also contributed to the theme since it was happy 50's music used as a motif to portray happiness, which goes along with most childhood memories especially those with your friends. In conclusion, enjoy your childhood while you still have it. As this movie teaches the viewer, it goes by way too fast. We always seem to take time for granted and issues that occurred while we were young seemed such a big deal then but now we know that they were trivial compared to issues that we have to face as adults.

Author: 2 June 2018
Review_Url: 'Stand By Me' is a moving coming-of-age film, with brilliant directing by Rob Reiner and commendable acting from its young cast. This film may have it's few little flaws, but they are ultimately overlooked by the amount of heart in this movie. This film had me emotionally invested from the first scene and has resonated deeply within me. I have never watched a movie before that made me ponder so much about my own life and feel intense feelings of nostalgia. The simple, yet captivating story allows this film to focus on it's complex and relatable characters, which are all played superbly by the child actors. The two supporting characters out of the foursome, played by Corey Feldman and Jerry O'Connell, are not exactly likeable in the way you'd expect them to be, it's really the two main characters, played brilliantly by Wil Wheaton and River Phoenix, that are the highlight of the film and beautifully represent childhood friendships. When combined with Reiner's smart directing, striking cinematography by Thomas Del Ruth and the great selection of 50's music, you get a near-perfect and beautiful film about childhood, innocence, and death.

Author: 25 September 2020
Review_Url:
A heart-warming movie, "Stand by Me" takes place in the 50s and brings 4 best friends through an adventurous hike on the train tracks to find a dead body. Rob Reiner's 1986 film is a story of friendship and growing up. These boys have had some of the toughest lives but their stories are one reason this movie is so entertaining. You'd be surprised to learn what they deal with at such a young age. This film does a wonderful job of portraying young friendships during the 50s.
Centered around the difficulties children and families have gone through in the 50s, it realistically brings depth and meaning to what you have imagined during those times. Each of the boys have experienced tremendous pain in their lives. Either from family physical abuse, substance abuse, neglect, and/or death. All have suffered from poverty in these hard times. For example, Teddy grew up with a crazy father--that suffers from war PTSD--that also almost burnt off Teddy's ear. Another example is Chris, who grew up with a bad family and had a reputation that he would turn out bad too. These boys show most of the struggles civilians dealt with back in the 50s.
This friendship is as real as can be and they would do anything for each other. They make fun of each other, as most boys do, they do rebellious stunts that can get them in big trouble, make pinkie swears, but they also care for each other in a way that you don't see in most young friendships. When they get bullied by the older kids, they stick up for each other. They have deep conversations about what they are going through with each other. For example, Teddy tries to do something crazy by standing in front of the train tracks when a train was coming, but Chris pulled him off and yelled at him to knock some sense into him. Another example is when Gordie stays back with Vern when he has to crawl instead of walk on the train tracks on a high bridge since he is afraid of heights. They all love, support, and take care of each other.
In my opinion, they are only 12 and too young for some of the activities that they do. This is mainly because of the environment they are around that force them to be more mature. In the movie, they are out and about without their parents knowing or caring about where they are. They also smoke cigarettes throughout the movie like it is normal. Chris also had a gun which he shouldn't have had excess too. Them acting this way shows the difference between life back then and how life is now.
The directors chose amazing characters that fit the plot perfectly. The main character, Gordie, narrates the movie from himself as an adult, telling the story of him and his friends at a young age. The character is smarter than the other boys and has better chances of a great future. The only thing is, his brother had just passed away and his mother and father ignore him now, since his brother was the favorite. Chris, who is Gordie's best friend, is the leader of the group and has a very compassionate side. He is empathic towards Gordie and is always hard on himself. Teddy has an emotional side when it comes to his father. Vern is clueless character that is brings humor to the movie. They all make fun of him but not to be mean; it's just them being friends. Each of the characters make you feel empathic towards them. They are what makes the movie so great.
"Stand by me" brings funny and traumatic events wrapped up into a powerful movie. It truly shows the strength of how young friendships impact a person with the last line of the movie said by Gordie as an adult, "I never really had any friends later on like the ones I had when I was twelve. ... Does anyone?" This line woke me up to the fact of how sad growing up really is. A bond of friendship is never the same as when we are young. I definitely recommend this movie to anyone who has a heart and the yearn for adventure and friendship.

Author: 21 October 2012
Review: The Social Experiment of Stand By Me
Review_Url: In the film Stand by Me, there are two groups of boys-to-men who are tribal in their relationships. One lead by "Ace" exist to destroy, bully, and inflict pain. The other led by "Chris" exist to find adventure, experience life without authority, and create opportunities to be heroes, even if misguided. Traditionally, as in West Side Story, the two gangs would meet and fight it out, over a woman or an insult. In this film, the two gangs compete for notoriety about discovering a dead kid's body, which is a sign of the times and the culture they live in. Life moved pretty slowly back then, and kids had to use their imaginations. I enjoyed how the film moved very calmly from one event to the next, using kick ass writing and acting instead of special effects to make the film interesting. Usually that combination is only found in independent films, so it's a credit to Rob Reiner and the perfect casting of the young, extremely talented actors, as well as the talented screen writing that this film will remain a classic for all time. River Phoenix stole the film, and established himself as one of the most gifted actors of all time. I thought Will Wheaton was a little stiff, but his fragile doe-eyed looks provided attributes to his character that his acting lacked. Corey Feldman was perfect as the child of a crazed post-traumatic war veteran...all fierce with innocently displaced loyalty to his abusive father. "Vern" was perfect as the nervously chattering fat kid who only wanted to be accepted as part of the group, less complex emotionally, and mostly interested in food. Keifer Sutherland was a little too convincing as the sadistic bully with his eternal sneer and dead eyes. His supportive crew were convincing as "tough guy" followers and wannabe gang members for that period of time. It would have been satisfying to hear what became of "Ace" and his gang in the final narration. I think Richard Dreyfuss was grossly miscast as the adult version of Will Wheaton's character, first of all because there is NO RESEMBLANCE whatsoever. Overall, the film is ageless as evidenced by the fact that my 18 year old son watched it recently and loved it as one of his favorite movies. It must speak to those feelings and emotions young males are reluctant to express openly; and the loyalties that develop between young boys who don't have great relationships with their fathers. Somehow the film is comforting in that way, and for that, it has accomplished the greatness of art imitating life.

Author: 8 February 2011
Review: Epic beyond belief for what it is.
Review_Url: "Stand By Me" truly is epic beyond belief for what it is. This is due to various reasons. 1). Its cast is mainly children. Quite often films with casts children dominated lack quality acting as the youngsters simply have just not been in the business long enough to be able to deliver impressive performances. However "Stand By Me"'s young cast all are believable and show great chemistry. River Phoenix in particular is amazing as the brave , yet troubled "Chris". 2). The film is very very short. Quite often the best films are around 2 hours in length. Often this duration is necessary for a film to drum up enough depth for it to stay with the viewer long after the credits. "Stand By Me" has no trouble going into decent amounts of depth and staying with the viewer in only 85 minutes. Its nice to watch a film which doesn't drag on. There is too many of that these days. 3).The focus of this film is on children so you would think it would probably only appeal to a childish audience.Yet it doesn't. It deals with some heavier material than initially expected but this is welcomed by more mature viewers. Plus most of us value our childhoods so its childhood friendship content is refreshing to view as it encourages us to reminisce on our good times of our younger days. In saying that it is epic for what it is I guess it was always going to be in some ways as its written by arguably the most successful writer of the 20th century Stephen King. Richard Dreyfus (Jaws) plays a satisfying side role as the older "Gordie" who narrates the story.

Review: Honest and powerful, Stand By Me is worth watching

What we see at the beginning are 4 simple, stereotypical characters; the smart one, the leader, the scared one and the funny one. King(the definitive version), "Everyday" By Buddy Holly, and "Great Balls of Fire" By Jerry Lee Lewis(Love that mailbox baseball!) just to mention a few. Review_Url: Stand by Me is a coming of age film starring Will Wheaton, River Phoenix, Corey Feldman, and Jerry O'Connell. The Movie is based upon the novel by Stephen King, "The Body." Four childhood friends embark on an adventure to find the body of a missing boy. The four friends are different from each other and each have their demons that they are battling. Throughout the film, their issues are unfolded which lead to the choices they make. Will Wheaton plays the lead, Gordie Lachance, a quiet, reserved character who is living in his late brother's shadow and with a resentful father, he bears guilt. River Phoenix plays Chris Chambers, who came from a bad family and is known as a thief. Corey Feldman plays Teddy Duchamp, a known physically abused kid. Jerry O'Connell plays Vern Tessio, the pathetic, easily teased, "fat kid". The editing effectively guides the audiences' thoughts, associations, and emotional responses right from the beginning sequence. In the beginning, we see the storyteller, played by Richard Dreyfuss, sitting in his pickup, looking into the distance as two young teens pedal by on their bicycles. He looks at a news article telling of a person's death. The camera zooms in slow motion focusing in on the expression of Dreyfuss' character who looks deep in thought. The zoom transitions into a start of a flashback as the narrator begins to voice-over the story. This one scene involves a massive amount of editing in such a small amount of time. The music in the background also sets an emotional tone. The kids on bicycles riding by, perhaps foreshadows that the story is about kids that age. And who is the person in the article of the paper? Will we find out? This scene is a great example of smooth continuity and coherence.

Review: An amazing, realistic and nostalgic experience.
Review_Url: I haven't read Stephen King's novel and I wasn't really sure if I was going to like this movie or not. My expectations were high, though. And it turned out to be one of my favorite movies of all time! The first thing that shocks you and leaves you speechless is the maturity of the main actors. Their acting seems to be so real, so down-to-earth and yet fascinating. I am not much of an emotional person and I do not often cry over movies, because there is always an inner voice telling me: This is not real, this is art, it is supposed to be entertainment. But this... It just hit me as hard as it could, I found myself with tears filling my eyes even the day after watching it. I am only 17, and I know that life is ahead of me, but for some reason it just made me feel nostalgic and old. It made me somehow regret watching it, but at the same time I want to watch it over and over again. I am not a movie expert, but for me - this was not a movie. This was my childhood, my memories, my desperate wish to turn back time. And maybe some more competent people criticize particular parts of this movie (for example, the main actors smiled in some scenes even though they were supposed to be serious), but for me these "flaws" made this movie perfect and real. They reminded me of me and my squad when we were that age, our pointless conversations, fights, joking, crying... For me, this movie is by far the best picture of that innocent stage in our lives. And a raw reminder that you'll never be that young and free again. But there are memories that help us. Memories - and things like this movie.

Author: 19 December 2011
Review_Url: The film "Stand By Me" is hands down one of my favorite movies of not only my childhood, but even still today. When I look back on my own youth around the years of 12-14, I can remember so clearly the moments portrayed in the film. Whether it be talking smack about our parents, running around all night saying we were each staying at different houses, or walking along the train tracks during the scorching summer days chucking rocks at the freights that passed by. I recall being skeptical at first about watching this so called "classic," simply because of the fact that i was an adolescent girl and not some "young dirty boy" taking hikes to see dead bodies and smoking cigarettes along the way. But from the minute the movie started with all the boys' playing cards in the famous tree house to the moment where Chris Chambers fades away at his and Gordie's final goodbye, I could not help but get a thousand of overwhelming emotions passing through me. I laughed, I cried, I felt angry, and at times even surprised by some of the language that these thirteen year old boys were using. But that is the magic of it all. How often does a movie about pre-teen kids come along where there is no sugar coating, just a plain and real depiction of how all of us acted when we were that age. The average movie always leaves me laughing or feeling entertained for the night, but very so often a dime piece will come along that leaves you in awe feeling nostalgic for days about your own childhood. And then there are the actors - how could I possibly forget about them? River Phoenix with his heart-gripping scene about the milk money, Whil Wheaton so believably portraying a quiet and vulnerable boy who had lost his brother, Corey Feldman evoking so much anger and hurt through the words he says and the emotion in his eyes, and then Jerry O'Connell-just being plain old, clumsy Vern. Rob Reiner also did a fantastic job to have the ability to take a Stephen King novel and turn it into a heartwarming tale that still held the "spooky" element to it all. Filled with an outstanding cast and beautiful theme song, it is no wonder this is a movie I cannot seem to go a year without watching. It is definitely a must see for anyone who feels they want to relive their past every now and again. Like the famous quote says, "I never had any friends later on like the ones I had when I was twelve. Jesus, does anyone?"

Review: After the death of a friend, a writer tells the story of a journey to find a body that him and his 3 friends went on as a boy.
Review_Url: Stephen King's "Stand by Me," is a movie about friendship and the freedom and innocence of adolescence. The main characters in the movie are Gordie Lechance, Chris Chambers, Vern Tessio, and Teddy Duchamp. Each one of them have imperfect lives that perfectly reveal who they are and how they act. Chris Chambers is the hard nosed kid in the friendship. The way that he talks about his father and the fact that he smokes suggests that he lives a hard life and that he is thought of badly by his peers. Gordie Lechance is the leader in the friendship. Gordie struggles with the emotional gap that he cant seem to fill in between him and his parents. You will find out why his parents have gone astray from him once you get later on into the movie. Vern Tessio is the gullible klutz of the group. He is often seen being teased by the other 3 boys. And last but not least Teddy Duchamp. Teddy is the free spirited member of the group that is crazy and likes to take risks. But don't let that fool you, behind all of his smiles and jokes there is a wall of emotion just waiting to cave in. When I watched this movie I felt that there was never a dull moment. I feel that for every part in this movie there is something to be learned. And for that, "Stand by Me," has easily become one of my favorite films and it will be of great benefit to those who watch it.

Review_Url: Stand By Me is a brilliant film. It is brutally honest and at times even too personal. This is shown brilliantly at the end of the movie when its protagonist, Gordie Lachance, now a man with two kids and a successful career as a writer, typing these exact words into his computer: "Do we really ever have friends as good as the ones when we were twelve?". That one line left a massive gulp in my throat for an hour the film ended, showing this really is one of the best coming-of-age films there is (and probably ever will be).

Author: 7 June 2013
Review: They don't make movies like this anymore
Review_Url: Stand By Me a nostalgic remembrance of a friendship between four twelve year old boys, during a period when they're just young enough to talk about cartoons and be afraid of the dark, and old enough to use cuss words and smoke cigarettes, and their biggest childhood adventure. They all have their own emotional problems and that's what makes their friendship so endearing to the viewer. The plot revolves around Gordie, an adult now with kids of his own, writing about the summer when his group friends found out about the location of a boy's dead body, a boy they all knew. Believing that it's what will bring them at least local fame, they set out to be the first who discover it, in the end competing with a much older gang. Stand by me is one of those movies that, no matter your gender, how old you are or how many times you've already seen it, it moves you. It makes you think of your childhood friends, the ones you haven't seen or heard in a long time and wonder if they think about you too, from time to time. The summers you spent in their company, playing or searching for a grand new adventure or when the adventure found you. This movie has those type of characters that are easily to relate to, even as a grown up. A brilliant masterpiece with heartwarming insights , the ecranisation of Stephen King's novella "The Body" will stand the passing of time because in every generation, there will be people who would find a bit of themselves in it. I give it 10/10.

Review: The Most Powerful Movie In The World
Review_Url: Never in my life have I seen a film like this. At first it seemed unappealing: four 12-year-old boys going to find a dead body. But by the time I was at the end, I was in tears. This is such a beautiful film. It revolves around Gordie Lachance, a sensitive boy who lost his brother and feels unloved and unappreciated by his dad. So when he hears of the body, he and his three friends, Chris Chambers, Teddy Duchamp and Vern Tessio, embark on a long journey down the train tracks to find it. The one scene that drove me to tears and I can never forget is when Gordie breaks down and cries over how his dad hates him and Chris, played beautifully by River Phoenix (may he rest in peace) is there to support him and make him feel good about himself and to be honest I think this film should have had two Oscars. One for Rob Reiner's superb directing and the other for the powerful and influential performance by River Phoenix.

Review: A dynamic horizon of friendship, loss and memory!
Review_Url: This really does atone for all the films that attempt to compress ideas of friendship, loss, bitterness and isolation together, because no film does it like Stand By Me. This film, although made in 1986 (i say this because of the amazing enhancements in technology in the past decade)chills me, and i cannot help taking a moment after the film's completion to regain a sense of bliss about the world. Because Stand By Me poses many questions about one's self- Who really are my mates? Are they worth living for? Are they worth dying for? And as River Phoenix portrays (brilliant actor) some things in the world are worth risking for, as his character fades into the winds of memory. I cannot help feel a sense of bereavement for River, seven years after the film, his character really does evaporate and it will be ten years this october (2003) since his death. Facing the dawn of youth, this film about four inquisitive kids grasps the inspiration they find in each other to carry on and live for each other- no matter what their parents think of them, they have three other mates that will make them laugh when things are bad, revamp their spirit when all is lost and make them cry because these times cannot last forever.
