Author: 3 March 1999
Review_Url: After Stephen King was asked by his publisher to write a 'non-supernatural' book, he initially refused. As he got used to the idea, he wrote a 4-novella's containing masterpiece, including 'Stand by me'. It's a genuine masterpiece telling of early teenager's chains of thoughts and displays realistically the fears, anxieties and all other important issues in 12-year old boy's minds. 'Stand by me' has a fantastic cast of, among others, Kiefer Sutherland and River Phoenix. The original title of the story, 'The body', was renamed 'Stand by me' after the title song, which occurs throughout the whole film in various adaptions and reflects the specific moods of the moment. I have seen this film in a time-span of about 8 years about 10 times. It seems crazy, but it's the truth. The film is perfect in all its aspects: beginning, plot, characters, '2nd level', and even ending (not one of King's strong points).The  film contains no gore, blood, monsters or non-realistic elements as we're used to of King, but is, next to 'The Shawshank Redemption', his best movie. The movie definitely earns his spot in the IMDB top-250.

Review_Url: This movie, adapted from a book by Stephen King, is not like most of the horror films you may come to expect from this author. While yes, there is a sense or morbidity, this movie is really more about that moment in your adolescence when everything is changing, yet everything is just right. Stand By Me is about four boys who take a trip to see a dead body, and on the way find themselves growing up. There is just the right mix of boyhood (the fart jokes, the rhyming insults, the play-wrestling) and adulthood. The boys enjoy their time, yet are always looking ahead at school next year and whether their friendships will last. River Pheonix delivers an amazing performance as the kid that no one has faith in, and is one of the best child actors I have ever seen. When I heard that he was dead, I was disappointed; he would've been an even more amazing actor later on. Keifer Sutherland also did well as 'Ace', the bully chasing the four boys. He was sufficiently frightening enough to keep us on our toes throughout the movie. This movie is sweet, with a large dose of nostalgia. You want to remember when you were 12, what it was like. You want the boys to succeed in their future, which seems so uncertain. All in all, the line that really sums it up is the last line of the movie: "I never had friends quite like the ones I had when I was 12 years old. But h***, does anybody?"

Review: Rob Reiner know's how to adapt Stephen King's greatest novels
Review_Url: ---SPOILER REVIEW---- As I start to commence into the greatest hits of Stephen King, I can't say I've actually read "The Body" (Novelization of Stand By Me) However I have read Misery, and Rob Reiner obviously knows what he's doing with his source material. Stand By Me is about a journey of four boys of junior high age. What they intended on their journey wasn't the life changing revelations that succumbed in the events of the movies, but simply to find a dead body, bring it in and hopefully attain fame from it. Gordie, Chambers, Teddy and Vern, each fill their own role in the gang. Gordie is the protagonist of the story, and his revelation revolves around the death of his seemingly perfect brother, Denny, who's always supported Gordie no matter the judgment of his father, who's only ever cherished the accomplishments of Denny, while sweeping Gordie under the rug. There is a moment in the middle of the movie where Gordie is having a dream of his brothers funeral. Everyone is looking down at Denny's grave. Gordie's father puts his hand on Gordie's shoulder saying "It should've been you." Now I wasn't sure if this was actually what happened during the funeral, but Gordie wakes up directly after this, explaining to Chris(Chamber) that he didn't cry at his brother's funeral. This is presumably to point out the fact that during the dream, Gordie did not cry during the funeral so this could also mean that his father really did tell him that he'd with Gordie had died instead of Denny. This is portrayed in the movie's great use of dialogue in certain situations such as Gordie and Chamber's heart to heart conversations. Though the dialogue portrayed throughout most of the movie comes off as cheesy and unrealistic in terms of how the youth would speak otherwise, this could have just been dialogue taken from Stephen King's novel. Again, I didn't read the book, and I wasn't born in the 50's. Anyways, I thought the movie was great, and definitely sent an inspiring message to those who aspire to do something great for themselves. These are my basic feelings about the movie and the moments that stuck out to me most. 1,000 words isn't enough for a full review unfortunately.

Set in Castle Rock, a small town on the north-eastern side of Oregon, four young boys set out a life-changing journey to find a missing body that was rumored to be located near a local riverbank. While on this journey, the group of young teens experiences many valuable events that not only change who they are on the surface but also fundamentally change their outlook on life. Alongside its profound nostalgia, the film carries the audience in and out of a wide range of emotions from euphoria to anguish.

But if you're old enough to appreciate it, you'll definitely be sucked in by the plot and the characters. Gordie- the sensitive writer, Chris- the misunderstood peacekeeper and leader, Teddy- the wild, crazy kid who keeps the story interesting, and Vern- the pet who flinches when you punch the air in front of him.

Author: 5 January 2011
Review: Great film based off a great book
Review_Url: "Stand By Me" is probably Rob Reiners masterpiece. Based off the great Stephen King short story, "The Body", it is a tale about youth, growing up, bullies, bad relationships with parents and friendship. The plot is about 4 friends who find out about a teenager who was hit by a train a couple miles down the train-track, and set out to find his dead body. Each kid has family issues. Gordie's (Wil Wheaton) close brother who was loved more than him died in a car crash a year previously and his parents couldn't care less about him. Chris (River Phoenix) has two rebel brothers which gives him an instant bad rep and the fact that the town thinks he stole lunch money from school doesn't help it. Teddy (Corey Feldman) has a mental father who burnt both of his ears off on a stove and Teddy is almost as crazy as him. And Vern (Jerry O'Connell) is the chubby runt-of-the-pack who also has a rebel for a brother. The four characters have great chemistry and give entertaining and funny conversations. The film perfectly captures the environment, expressions and style of the 50's. There are several intense, surprising, funny and sad moments in this great adaptation. It is one of my favorite films.

Review: "stand by me" shows that children are more than capable of understanding, feeling and participating in previously described "adult concepts".
Review_Url: Modern "coming of age" Dramas seem to display notions of people under 15 years of age being innocents, free from corruption and unaware of tensions between associates of different sexes. Then along comes a catalyst in the shape of going to high school, making a new friend etc. and  all of a sudden a child becomes an adolescent, free from illusions and aware of adult issues. Usually the "coming of age" drama is focused around these issues; of first noticing the opposite sex, of the discovery of a "generation gap" between the subject/s and their parents/guardians, of the discovery of swearing and drinking and occasionally drugs. The thing I liked about this movie is that it highlights the fact that awareness of these issues does not come exclusively with puberty. The characters in this movie smoke, swear, tell dirty jokes, discuss sex, and hate their parents all before hitting their "Teens". It shows that it is naive to assume that it takes 15 years for a child to realise that there is a "generation gap" existing in their household. It also displays an underlying concept that many children are capable of acheiving personal skills that many adults are incapable of; that is the ability to make decisions and stick to them, the ability to lead a group, the ability to take care of themselves, and the ability to problem solve within a group. This concept, that many children depend on their parents for economic support more than emotional support is an edgy one and one that forces veiwers to redefine their mental image of the "child".
